title: Quiz 6: Community Health Nursing - January 2020 FQE
description: Final Qualifying Examination from January 2020. This quiz covers Section 1 (Multiple Choice Questions) focusing on Community Diagnosis, Vaccines, Communicable Diseases, and Management.

questions.question: The following are used for community diagnosis:

options.text: Maps, weighing scales, specimen bottles, questionaires
Record books, weighing scales, questionaires, specimen bottles
Thermometer, maps, weighing scales, specimen bottles

questions.explanation: Community diagnosis utilizes tools that assess the population and environment (maps, surveys, sampling). Clinical tools like stethoscopes and thermometers are for individual diagnosis.
questions.hint: Tools for population assessment, not individual clinical exam.

questions.question: Pillars of vision 2030 include:
questions.explanation: Kenya Vision 2030 is anchored on three key pillars: Economic, Social, and Political.

questions.question: The following are the Kenya high priority health packages:
questions.explanation: Traditional high priority packages in KEPH focus on communicable conditions and preventable diseases like Cholera and Typhoid due to their acute burden.

questions.question: One function of vitamin B12 is:

options.text: Keeps blood cells healthy and nerves

questions.explanation: Vitamin B12 is essential for red blood cell formation and nervous system maintenance.

questions.question: The original vaccines launched by EPI program includes:

options.text: Oral Polio Vaccine, Pentavalent, measles, Tetanus Toxoid
Bacilli Calmette Guerin, Diphtheria Pertussis Tetanus, Tetanus Toxoid, Oral Polio Vaccine
Diphtheria Pertussis Tetanus, Bacilli Calmette Guerin, Rota Virus, Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine

questions.explanation: The original EPI targeted 6 diseases: TB (BCG), Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus (DPT), Polio (OPV), and Measles.

questions.question: The shake test is used to monitor:
questions.explanation: The shake test determines if a freeze-sensitive vaccine has been damaged by freezing by observing the sedimentation rate.

questions.question: The criteria required for dental caries formation includes:
questions.explanation: Caries formation requires the host (tooth surface/dentin), bacteria, diet, and time.
questions.hint: The part of the tooth affected.

questions.question: The biotic factors to consider in ensuring a healthy environment includes:
questions.explanation: Biotic factors are the living components of the environment.

questions.question: The following is an example of water dispersed disease:
questions.explanation: Legionella proliferates in water systems and is dispersed via aerosols (water dispersed).

questions.question: Contamination involves:
questions.explanation: Contamination is the mere presence of an infectious agent on a surface or body, distinct from infection (lodgement/multiplication).

questions.question: The immunity acquired after successful vaccination is:
questions.explanation: Vaccines artificially stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies (Active).

questions.question: The following mineral forms half of the total body content:
questions.explanation: Calcium is the most abundant mineral in the body (bones/teeth).

questions.question: Levonorgestrel contraceptive pill acts within:

options.text: Up to 120 hours after unprotected sex
Up to 24 hours after unprotected sex
Up to 72 hours after unprotected sex
Up to one week after unprotected sex

questions.explanation: Levonorgestrel ECPs are most effective within 72 hours (3 days).

questions.question: The patch contraceptive is composed of:
questions.explanation: The patch is a combined hormonal method (Estrogen + Progestin).

questions.question: The effectiveness of progesterone only contraceptive is:
questions.explanation: With perfect use, progestin-only methods have >99% effectiveness.

questions.question: The sexually transmitted diseases caused by viruses include:
questions.explanation: Hep B and HPV are viral. Chlamydia and Syphilis are bacterial.

questions.question: The prevention of the spread of HIV includes condom use and one of the following:

options.text: Ensuring screening of some blood before transfusion
Ensuring research is continuously done to study the trends of viral mutation
Ensuring no gloving when cannulating HIV infected clients

questions.explanation: Screening blood products is a critical preventive strategy.

questions.question: The statement that describes the ultimate results of fulfilling an organization's purpose is:
questions.explanation: Vision describes the future state or ultimate result.

questions.question: Management functions include:
questions.explanation: Standard functions: Planning, Organizing, Staffing, Directing, Controlling.

questions.question: A valid health indicator is one that:

options.text: Is able to obtain the data needed
Should actually measure what it is supposed to measure
Is sensitive to changes in situations concerned
Reflects changes only in the situation concerned

questions.explanation: Validity = Accuracy of measurement.

questions.question: The following are some of the morbidity indicators in a community:
questions.explanation: Incidence and Prevalence measure morbidity (illness). Death rates measure mortality.

questions.question: The following are viral communicable diseases:
questions.explanation: Polio, Rubella, and Varicella are all viruses.

questions.question: Incidence rate in disease is used to measure:

options.text: The length the disease lasts in the population
The population at risk in the middle of the year
New cases occurring in the population
The need for prevention of disease

questions.explanation: Incidence measures new cases.

questions.question: Demographic data is best collected through:
questions.explanation: A census is the most comprehensive method for demographic data.

questions.question: The process of social change involves:
questions.explanation: Social change is driven by discovery, invention, and innovation.

questions.question: Match the disease vector or reservoir with the disease it transmits:
questions.explanation: Dogs host Hydatid; Sandflies transmit Leishmaniasis; Rat fleas transmit Plague; C. tetani causes Tetanus.

questions.question: In ascribed status, the individual acquires position through:
questions.explanation: Ascribed status is assigned (e.g., by birth/inheritance), not earned.

questions.question: The standard case definition for measles disease includes:

options.text: Fever, loss of appetite, loss of weight

questions.explanation: Measles definition: Fever + Rash + (Cough/Coryza/Conjunctivitis).

questions.question: When triaging in disaster management, a casualty who is disoriented and has weak irregular pulse with rapid respirations is coded:
questions.explanation: Signs of shock and altered mental status indicate immediate life threat (Red priority).

questions.question: Biological perspective of psychology involves:
questions.explanation: Biological perspective focuses on the physical/neurological basis of behavior.

questions.question: The causative organism of the disease tetanus is:
questions.explanation: Clostridium tetani bacteria cause tetanus.

questions.question: During growth and development, the term cephalocaudal means:

options.text: Changes in the spatial proportion over time
Changes in the independence of systems

questions.explanation: Cephalocaudal means development proceeds from head to tail (changes in spatial proportion).

questions.question: According to the period of development, childhood occurs from:
questions.explanation: Childhood covers approx 3 to 12 years (Early and Late childhood).

questions.question: The routine data collection tool that allows for continuity of service delivery in a child welfare clinic is:

options.text: Immunization and Vitamin A summary sheet

questions.explanation: The MCH Booklet is kept by the mother and tracks history across visits.

questions.question: In community strategy, the unit of analysis is:
questions.explanation: The household is the primary unit for data collection in community strategy.

questions.question: The following is a type of family based on dominance (Lineage/Residence):
questions.explanation: While 'dominance' refers to Patriarchal/Matriarchal, Lineage (Patrilineal/Matrilineal) is often the intended answer in this context when dominance options are missing.

questions.question: Some of the essential elements of a referral system include:

options.text: Service availability, feedback mechanism, community mobilization
Coordination of referral services, communication and transport, feedback mechanism

questions.explanation: Referral requires coordination, communication, transport, and feedback.

questions.question: The last stage of nurse-client relationship in the communication process is referred to as:
questions.explanation: The final phase is Termination.

questions.question: The pillars of Primary Health Care include:

options.text: Intersectoral collaboration, community participation, access to health facilities
Appropriate technology, intersectoral collaboration, community participation
Support mechanisms, appropriate technology, efficient service delivery

questions.explanation: Participation, Intersectoral Collaboration, and Appropriate Technology are core pillars.

questions.question: Arrange the following vaccines in order of vulnerability to freezing (Most to Least):
questions.explanation: Hep B freezes at -0.5C (most sensitive), followed by DPT, then TT.
